slides.title: NeuraPlox — The AI Operating Platform for European Enterprises
slides.headline: What SAP did for business processes, NeuraPlox will do for AI agents.
slides.speaker_notes: Open with the SAP line — it is instantly legible to any European enterprise investor. Do not over-explain the technology on this slide. Let the revenue number do the work: a bootstrapped team generating over two million euros in year two is proof of demand, not just ambition.
slides.transition_to_next: To understand why that demand exists and why every engagement pointed to the same root cause, let me show you the problem we kept finding inside every client.
vc_alignment_notes: European sovereignty angle embedded in framing — 'European enterprises' signals deliberate positioning against US hyperscalers
Capital efficiency signal: >€2M bootstrapped is exactly the revenue-to-raised ratio Earlybird prizes
SAP analogy resonates with Earlybird's portfolio thesis of category-creation (remberg, HiveMQ precedents)

slides.title: AI Infrastructure Built From 25 Deployments, Not Hypotheses
slides.headline: Neurawork spent two years deploying AI inside Mittelstand enterprises — every project revealed the same gap. NeuraPlox closes it.
bullets: 25+ live enterprise AI deployments → confirmed: companies fail at infrastructure, not ambition
>€2M revenue, bootstrapped, year two — 100% consulting/services, zero external capital
NeuraPlox: 7-layer AI platform → cuts infrastructure cost from 60% to <30% of project spend, deployment from 3-6 months to <6 weeks
Raising €3M Seed to productize the architecture already running in live enterprise environments
slides.speaker_notes: The key insight to land here is sequence: most AI platform companies build first and find customers second. We did it backwards — we deployed first, found the pattern, then built the product. That is why our architecture specification is not a whiteboard exercise. It is derived from two years of production failure modes.
slides.transition_to_next: Let me be precise about what that infrastructure failure looks like — because it is not random. It is the same five structural problems, repeated across every engagement.
vc_alignment_notes: Demand-first narrative matches Earlybird's industrial/enterprise domain expertise thesis
Capital efficiency highlighted: >€2M on zero raised capital is a burn multiple of effectively zero
25+ deployments satisfy requirement for customer evidence before product completion

slides.title: The Mittelstand AI Gap: 86% Intent, 23% Execution
slides.headline: European SMEs want AI but fail systematically at infrastructure — not at ambition or use cases.
bullets: 63-point intention-action gap: 86% of German SMEs cite AI as strategically critical, only 23% have successfully operationalized a single AI project (maximal.digital, 2025)
60% cost waste: In every AI project without a standardized platform, ~60% of budget goes to rebuilding the same infrastructure — data connectors, auth, deployment — from scratch every time
N×M explosion: 3 AI agents + 5 data sources = 15 individual integrations to build, test and maintain; 10×10 = 100 — the complexity is combinatorially fatal for small IT teams
73% of enterprises report insufficient control over AI agent behavior (Langflow/DataStax, 2025) — AI runs in production without security guardrails
metrics: 63% of SME AI projects exceed budget by avg. 34% (maximal.digital, 2025)
82% of Mittelstand report significant AI engineering skill gap (maximal.digital, 2025)
0.35% of revenue invested in AI vs. market average — 30% below benchmark (Horvath, 2025)
slides.speaker_notes: Do not frame this as a technology education problem. The data shows these companies understand AI — 86% of them have made it a strategic priority. The failure is purely structural: there is no reusable foundation to build on, so every project starts at zero. The N×M integration problem is the most visceral version of this — draw it if needed. Three agents, five data sources, fifteen individual integrations. Add one data source and you rebuild half of them.
slides.transition_to_next: This problem has existed for two years — the question is why now is the moment it becomes urgent enough for enterprises to buy a platform rather than tolerate the waste.
vc_alignment_notes: Data-driven problem framing with named third-party sources matches Earlybird's stated preference for evidence-based narratives
Security framing (73% uncontrolled agent behavior) sets up the correct value proposition hierarchy per neuraplox_updates.md guidance
Mittelstand focus aligns with Earlybird's industrial/enterprise domain expertise thesis and existing portfolio (remberg)

slides.title: Three Simultaneous Forces Are Collapsing the Status Quo
slides.headline: A regulatory deadline, a capability inflection, and a proven deployment pattern have created a narrow window to own the category.
bullets: EU AI Act hard deadline — August 2026: High-risk AI systems require mandatory governance infrastructure. 56% of German companies currently have no compliant architecture. This is not a future problem — it is 12 months away (EU 2024/1689)

Agent-native AI has crossed the production threshold: LLM-based multi-agent systems are moving from R&D to daily operations in 2025-26. Gartner: 40%+ of enterprise apps will embed AI agents by 2026. The infrastructure layer does not yet exist for SMEs

Hyperscaler lock-in awareness is peaking: 93% of German enterprises prefer German/EU AI providers (Bitkom, 2025). US hyperscaler dependency — Azure, AWS, GCP — is now a board-level procurement risk, not just a technical preference

European sovereign AI funding: BMWK deploying >€5B into AI infrastructure and sovereignty. GAIA-X, SOOFI, IPCEI-AI collectively creating regulatory tailwind and co-investment potential for EU-native platforms
metrics: August 2026: EU AI Act high-risk deadline
93% German enterprise preference for EU AI providers (Bitkom, 2025)
slides.speaker_notes: The August 2026 deadline is the sharpest forcing function. Mention it as a concrete date, not a concept. For an IT director in a German manufacturing company, that date already has an item on the board agenda. The second point — agent-native AI reaching production — is the capability unlock. And the third — 93% preference for EU providers — is the distribution advantage. These three things are happening simultaneously for the first time.
slides.transition_to_next: So here is exactly what we built — not in a lab, but iteratively across 25 live enterprise deployments — to solve these three forces simultaneously.
vc_alignment_notes: EU AI Act deadline satisfies Earlybird's European digital sovereignty investment thesis directly
Category creation timing narrative: the infrastructure category for agentic AI does not yet have a Mittelstand winner
BMWK funding context is relevant to Earlybird's thesis on European sovereign AI (Aleph Alpha precedent in portfolio)

slides.title: NeuraPlox: The AI Operating Platform — Security First, Compliance by Design
slides.headline: NeuraPlox is the production infrastructure layer that lets Mittelstand IT teams run AI agents safely, without rebuilding the same foundation for every project.
bullets: What it is: A 7-layer Kubernetes-native AI platform — from deployment runtime to agent registry — that turns any AI use case into a production-ready, secure, governed operation in <6 weeks

Security first: Every agent has a unique identity, permission matrix, and behavioral boundary. No agent can access data or call an LLM without passing a 3D security policy check (Who × What × Which Data) — the platform equivalent of a next-gen firewall for AI
N+M connector architecture: Connect M data sources once to the platform. Every new AI agent automatically inherits all connections — reducing integration complexity from N×M to N+M
Operational AI model: 50% technology (NeuraPlox), 50% human (Neurawork's change management and TÜV SÜD-certified training). AI that doesn't run in daily operations is not a result

Quantified impact: Infrastructure cost share reduced from ~60% → <30% of AI project spend; deployment time from 3-6 months → <6 weeks; single-project self-build cost €80-150K vs. NeuraPlox from €24K/year
metrics: Platform vs. self-build: €24K/year vs. €80-150K per project
slides.speaker_notes: Lead with security, not compliance. The framing is: you don't buy a firewall because of GDPR — you buy it because you don't want your business operations compromised. NeuraPlox is the security and operations layer for AI agents. Compliance with EU AI Act is a byproduct of that architecture, not the reason to buy. The N+M connector visual is worth drawing: it is the clearest illustration of the compounding cost savings.
slides.transition_to_next: Let me show you the architecture in more detail — specifically the seven layers and why the combination is the defensible moat, not any single component.
vc_alignment_notes: Security-first framing aligns with enterprise software value proposition that Earlybird portfolio companies (remberg, HiveMQ) use
Operational AI model with human component addresses AI deployment failure modes identified in Earlybird's deep-tech portfolio thesis
Cloud-agnostic, Kubernetes-native architecture supports European sovereignty positioning

slides.title: 7-Layer Architecture: The AI Operating System for Enterprises
slides.headline: No single layer is novel — the defensible moat is their standardized, integrated combination, built specifically for enterprises without large ML engineering teams.
bullets: ECOSYSTEM (top): Ploxe — modular AI agents built by Neurawork, customers, or third-party developers via SDK. Includes 'Agents of Prism': analytics, marketing, sales, and contract agents replacing entire consulting verticals

CONTROL PLANE (L4-L7): Agent Registry & Lifecycle (L7) → Policy & Governance Engine with 3D security model (L6) → Unified Data Access with PII detection for German-language documents (L5) → Multi-Agent Observability with real-time cost attribution (L4)

EXECUTION LAYER (L1-L3): AI & Intelligence with LLM gateway + hybrid-search RAG engine (L3) → MLOps & Data with MLflow model registry + vector database (L2) → Deployment & Runtime: Kubernetes operator, ArgoCD GitOps, multi-tenant isolation (L1)

Agent Marketplace (Horizon 3): Third-party developers build and sell specialized agents through NeuraPlox — Salesforce AppExchange logic applied to AI agents. Platform earns 15-25% revenue share on every transaction
Open execution layer (L1-L3 open source) + proprietary control plane (L4-L7) = AWS playbook: no lock-in by design, yet customers stay because they build competence on the platform
metrics: >95% PII detection precision/recall target (German-language business documents)
slides.speaker_notes: Walk investors down the architecture from top to bottom. The key message is: LangChain solves agent logic. Langdock solves the chat interface. NeuraPlox is the operating infrastructure between the data and the agent — the layer that neither framework nor SaaS tool addresses. The open-source execution layer + proprietary control plane split is intentional: it mirrors the AWS playbook where openness builds trust and stickiness, not dependency.
slides.transition_to_next: With the architecture clear, let me show you the size of the market we are building this for — and why the bottom-up numbers are more compelling than any top-down TAM.
vc_alignment_notes: Dr. Andre Retterath (Earlybird partner) specifically focuses on developer tools and OSS — the open-source L1-L3 + proprietary L4-L7 strategy directly maps to his investment thesis
Agent marketplace = platform economics, network effects, category creation — all core Earlybird criteria
Technical depth required for AI-specific investors is demonstrated through the layer architecture

slides.title: €1.5B DACH Beachhead — €94B Global Platform Opportunity by 2030
slides.headline: Bottom-up: 30,000 addressable Mittelstand companies × €50K average ACV = €1.5B SAM. EU AI Act makes this a 27-country expansion with zero architecture changes.
bullets: ICP universe (DACH): 70,000 German enterprises with 50-500 employees (IfM Bonn) × projected 45% AI adoption rate by 2027 = 30,000 addressable accounts (SAM)
Bottom-up SAM: 30,000 accounts × €50,000 average ACV (blended managed service + customer cloud) = €1.5B/year DACH addressable revenue
SOM Year 3: 50 customers × €60,000 average ACV = €3M ARR — less than 0.2% SAM penetration; this is a sales capacity constraint, not a market constraint

EU expansion lever: EU AI Act governance layer is identical across all 27 member states — no country-specific product adaptation required. Phase 2 targets Netherlands, France, Nordics via channel partners. EU-27 TAM equivalent: ~€10B SAM
metrics: TAM: €94B global AI platform market by 2030 (38.9% CAGR, MarketsandMarkets)
slides.speaker_notes: Start with the bottom-up. Investors have seen too many top-down TAMs. The number that matters is: 70,000 Mittelstand companies in our size band, 45% will need AI infrastructure by 2027, 30,000 addressable accounts, average €50K ACV. That's €1.5 billion. We need 50 of those 30,000 in year three to hit €3M ARR — that is a distribution problem, not a market problem. Then explain the EU expansion: we don't have to localize the product because the governance layer is already EU-27 compliant by design.
slides.transition_to_next: The market is large and the expansion lever is built into the architecture. Now let me show you how we capture it — the business model and unit economics.
vc_alignment_notes: Bottom-up methodology explicitly required by Earlybird — delivered with ICP count and ARPU visible
EU-27 expansion narrative directly addresses Earlybird's requirement for global winner potential from European base
SOM Year 3 of €3M ARR is conservative and credible — Earlybird values realism in near-term projections

slides.title: Three Revenue Horizons — Platform to Marketplace to Operations
slides.headline: Horizon 1 consulting validates demand (today). Horizon 2 SaaS platform captures it (Seed). Horizon 3 marketplace and Operations as a Service scale it (Series A).
bullets: H1 — Consulting/Services (now): €2M+ revenue, ~30% gross margin. Not a liability — it is the demand validation engine and customer acquisition channel for the platform. Every engagement becomes a NeuraPlox pilot
H2 — SaaS Platform (Seed build): Managed Service €2K-8K/month (€24K-96K ACV); Customer Cloud €1.5K-5K/month. Target gross margin 70%+. ZIM grant (€237K, 45% of R&D) co-funds the build

H3 — Marketplace + Operations as a Service (Series A): 15-25% revenue share on third-party agent transactions + Operations as a Service (monitoring, optimization, compliance operations). Target gross margin 80%+. Shopify analogy: Merchant Solutions drove 75% of Shopify Q3 2025 revenue vs. 25% subscriptions
Land-and-expand flywheel: Enter with 1-2 Ploxe (AI agents) → average Plox count grows 1-2 (Y1) to 4-6 (Y3) as infrastructure reuse compounds → ACV expands without proportional CAC increase
Pricing moat: Self-build cost €80-150K per AI project (60% infrastructure) vs. NeuraPlox from €24K/year — platform pays back on project 1, compounds from project 2 onward
slides.speaker_notes: The three-horizon model is critical to articulate clearly. Some investors will see consulting as a distraction. Reframe it: consulting is how we acquire customers at near-zero CAC, validate architecture in production, and generate the revenue that has kept us alive without raising a euro. The Shopify Merchant Solutions analogy is your most powerful tool for explaining why Operations as a Service will eventually dwarf platform subscriptions in revenue.
slides.transition_to_next: The business model is designed. The question is whether the market is responding. Here is what the traction data shows.
vc_alignment_notes: Three-horizon model demonstrates gross margin trajectory — Earlybird explicitly tracks this metric
Capital efficiency is central: consulting revenue funded the product discovery phase; Seed is purely for product and engineering acceleration
ZIM grant (€237K public co-funding) reduces dilutive capital needs — reinforces capital-efficient growth signal

slides.title: €2M Revenue, Zero Raised — Platform Architecture Validated in 25 Live Deployments
slides.headline: Every metric is organic: no marketing spend, no sales team, no external capital. Pure demand signal from the Mittelstand.
bullets: >€2M revenue in year two, bootstrapped — entirely from enterprises paying for AI deployment and architecture work (consulting/services revenue; platform ARR is the Seed build target)
25+ enterprise AI deployments completed: due diligence AI, automated order processing, care worker placement automation, warehouse logistics AI — across DACH Mittelstand verticals

4 live pilot projects currently validating NeuraPlox architecture components with real enterprise data: financial services (document intelligence), real estate investment (data integration), professional services (ML pattern recognition), tax advisory (ML bookkeeping automation)
Architecture validation metrics from live deployments: ~60% infrastructure cost share confirmed across projects; deployment time baseline 3-6 months confirmed — platform target <6 weeks
93% of German enterprises prefer German AI providers (Bitkom, 2025) — Neurawork's TÜV SÜD certification and German data residency give us institutional credibility that US hyperscalers cannot match
slides.speaker_notes: Anticipate the obvious question: 'This is consulting revenue, not SaaS.' Agree, and then reframe: 25 paying enterprise customers in two years with zero marketing spend and zero external capital is not a consulting business — it is a proof-of-distribution for the platform. These companies are already paying Neurawork to build what NeuraPlox productizes. The conversion from consulting client to platform subscriber is the lowest-friction enterprise sale imaginable. Note: if an investor pushes for single-case ROI data, cite the aggregate: across 25 deployments, infrastructure consistently consumed 60% of project budget, which NeuraPlox architecture directly eliminates.
slides.transition_to_next: The demand is proven. Now let me show you how we systematically scale from 25 deployments to 500 — the go-to-market motion.
vc_alignment_notes: Traction section directly addresses Earlybird's requirement for named or anonymized customer evidence — 4 active pilots provide vertical-specific proof
Zero capital raised with >€2M revenue is a capital efficiency signal that directly maps to Earlybird's burn multiple criteria
TÜV SÜD certification addresses Earlybird's European sovereignty thesis with institutional validation

slides.title: Consulting Pipeline → Platform Conversion → Ecosystem Flywheel
slides.headline: The go-to-market machine is already running: consulting engagements are the inbound motion that converts directly into platform subscriptions at near-zero incremental CAC.
bullets: ICP: IT directors, CTOs, and technical CEOs at DACH enterprises with 50-500 employees who have initiated at least one AI project and hit the infrastructure wall — they are already in pain, already budget-allocated, already educated

Motion 1 — Consulting-to-platform conversion (primary): Consulting engagement → NeuraPlox pilot (architecture validated on client data) → managed service subscription. CAC is absorbed by consulting revenue; platform conversion requires no additional sales cycle

Motion 2 — Direct sales (Seed-funded): 1 solution architect hire post-Seed for outbound to warm pipeline. Target: 10 new platform customers year one via direct technical sales to CTOs identified through content marketing and event presence (Hannover Messe, Bitkom Digital)

Motion 3 — Partner channel (Year 2): 5-10 IT consultancies and system integrators receive Plox SDK access and co-sell incentives. Each partner brings their own installed base of Mittelstand clients — distribution without Neurawork headcount

EU expansion (Year 2-3): EU AI Act compliance layer requires zero product changes for Netherlands, France, Nordics — channel partners in target markets activate with existing platform. Agent Marketplace creates supply-side pull: third-party developers in any EU country list agents, pulling local enterprises onto the platform
metrics: Primary CAC: Near-zero (absorbed by consulting engagement revenue)
Year 1 target: 10 new platform customers via direct sales
slides.speaker_notes: The consulting-to-platform conversion motion is the key insight. Most enterprise software companies pay €50K-100K to acquire a single customer. Neurawork gets paid to acquire them. A consulting engagement delivers revenue, validates the platform architecture in the client's environment, and creates the reference case for the platform sale — simultaneously. That is the structural advantage of starting demand-first. Post-Seed, the first hire is a solution architect, not a salesperson: technical sales to CTOs, not marketing-led demand generation.
slides.transition_to_next: The sales motion is differentiated. Let me show you how NeuraPlox is positioned versus the competitive landscape — and why the comparison is more nuanced than it first appears.
vc_alignment_notes: Consulting-as-CAC model is highly capital-efficient — directly addresses Earlybird's burn multiple focus
EU expansion via channel partners with zero product localization demonstrates the European sovereignty architecture advantage
Agent marketplace supply-side pull is a network effect narrative that Earlybird specifically looks for in platform companies

slides.title: NeuraPlox Occupies an Uncontested Position: Infrastructure Depth × Mittelstand Accessibility
slides.headline: No existing category serves the intersection of full AI infrastructure stack and sub-€100K annual cost — NeuraPlox is creating this category.
bullets: Axis 1 — Infrastructure depth (low = application layer, high = full platform stack): Hyperscalers (Azure AI, AWS SageMaker) and Enterprise platforms (Dataiku, Palantir Foundry) are high depth but locked to enterprise budgets (€48K-€150K+/year minimum). Langdock, Copilot, Glean are low depth — application wrappers, not infrastructure

Axis 2 — Mittelstand accessibility (low = requires ML engineering teams, high = operable by small IT teams): All enterprise-depth solutions require ML engineering teams. All SME-accessible solutions lack infrastructure depth. NeuraPlox is the only solution in the high-depth, high-accessibility quadrant

Key differentiator: 3D Security Policy Model (Who × What × Which Data) treats AI agents as first-class security identities — no other platform implements agent-level permission matrices with full audit trail. This is the technical moat that compliance tools (NeMo Guardrails) and application platforms (Langdock) cannot replicate without rebuilding from the infrastructure layer

European sovereignty moat: Cloud-agnostic architecture (Azure/AWS/GCP/on-premise), German data residency, TÜV SÜD certification, and EU AI Act compliance by design — structural advantages that US-origin platforms cannot credibly match for German enterprise procurement teams
metrics: Palantir Foundry: €150K+/year minimum vs. NeuraPlox €24K/year (6-10x cost advantage)
Dataiku: €48K/year minimum vs. NeuraPlox €24K/year (2x cost advantage at entry)
Open-source frameworks (LangChain, CrewAI): Free but €80-150K self-build cost per project
slides.speaker_notes: The competitive slide should not be framed as 'we are better than Langdock.' Langdock is an application; NeuraPlox is infrastructure. They serve different layers of the stack. The real competition is the self-build status quo — enterprises spending €80-150K per AI project on infrastructure they rebuild from scratch every time. That is the competitor. The 3D security policy model is the technical differentiator worth dwelling on: it is the first time AI agents have been treated as security identities with their own permission scopes, rather than as extensions of human user accounts.
slides.transition_to_next: Category creation is a team sport — let me show you why this founding team is uniquely qualified to own this category.
vc_alignment_notes: Category creation narrative ('uncontested position') directly maps to Earlybird's stated focus on companies defining new categories (UiPath/RPA, remberg/XRM precedents)
European sovereignty moat is a defensibility argument specifically relevant to Earlybird's thesis
Competitive analysis addresses AI commoditization risk proactively: the moat is the integrated architecture + security model, not any single AI model

slides.title: Demand-First Founders: PwC + Allianz/Oliver Wyman + TÜV SÜD
slides.headline: The founding team has lived inside Mittelstand AI failures as advisors, as operators, and as engineers — NeuraPlox is what they wish had existed.
bullets: Christoph Knoell (CEO — Product, Strategy & Technology): Former PwC Senior Manager Transactions (M&A, IT & AI strategy); TÜV SÜD Innovator. Led complex IT transformation projects in carve-outs, due diligence and post-merger integration — project volumes in the double-digit millions. Brings enterprise architecture pattern recognition from 100+ client engagements

Sylvia Knoell (Managing Director — Operations & Finance): Transformation expertise from Allianz and Oliver Wyman. Owns operations, customer delivery, and financial management. The Operational AI methodology (strategy + architecture + change management) is built on her change management and training expertise

Engineering team: 4-5 engineers with demonstrated production capability across Kubernetes-native ML pipelines, multi-tenancy configurations, German NLP (spaCy, Flair), EU AI Act compliance architecture, and RAG implementation

Institutional credibility beyond team size: TÜV SÜD-certified AI training practice — the most recognized industrial certification authority in German enterprise procurement. Earns trust in rooms where startup pedigree alone would not

€2M revenue with 4-5 engineers is the proof point: this is exceptional capital efficiency, not a lean team. The Seed funds targeted scaling — 2-3 senior engineers + 1 sales/partnerships lead — not a hiring spree
metrics: 2 years domain experience: 25+ enterprise AI deployments
TÜV SÜD certification: institutional credibility in German enterprise
slides.speaker_notes: Pre-empt the 'small team for this market' objection immediately: €2M revenue with 4-5 people is the answer. The question is not whether this team can execute — the revenue proves they can. The question is whether the Seed will be used efficiently, and the planned post-Seed hires are surgical: 2-3 senior engineers to complete the platform build, 1 sales/partnerships lead. The TÜV SÜD angle is particularly strong in German enterprise: it is institutional trust that US-origin startups cannot replicate regardless of funding. Note: confirm Sylvia Knoell's first name before any investor meeting — listed as '[Vorname]' in source documents.
slides.transition_to_next: With the team clear, let me walk through the financial picture — current state, use of Seed capital, and the path to Series A.
vc_alignment_notes: Founders' industrial/enterprise domain expertise directly maps to Earlybird's investment criterion for 'deep vertical domain understanding'
Capital efficiency of >€2M revenue with 4-5 engineers is exactly the ratio Earlybird targets
TÜV SÜD certification addresses European sovereignty and trust signals in the Earlybird portfolio context (vs. US-origin competitors)

slides.title: Revenue Today Funds Discovery — Seed Funds the Platform
slides.headline: Bootstrapped to >€2M in two years. The Seed is not survival capital — it is acceleration capital for a team that has already proven it can generate revenue.
bullets: Revenue trajectory: Year 1 (consulting ramp) → Year 2 >€2M (consulting/services, bootstrapped, zero external capital) → Year 3 target: €600K platform ARR + consulting → Year 4 target: €2.4M platform ARR (40 customers × avg €60K ACV)
Three-horizon gross margin step-up: Consulting ~30% GM (today) → SaaS platform 70%+ GM (Seed output) → Marketplace + OaaS 80%+ GM (Series A scale) — margin expansion is architectural, not operational
R&D co-funding: €237K ZIM grant (45% of €527K R&D budget) approved — reduces dilutive Seed capital requirements and validates the technical novelty of the architecture with a German government agency

Path to Series A: €3M Seed funds 18-month product build + first 10 platform customers. Series A trigger: €1.5-2M ARR with 15+ platform customers and EU expansion channel activated — expected 18-24 months post-Seed close
metrics: Burn rate: [NOTE — specific monthly burn not disclosed in source documents; must be confirmed before investor meeting]
slides.speaker_notes: Two things to land hard here: First, the non-dilutive ZIM grant reduces how much Seed capital is consumed by R&D — €237K of the product build is already co-funded. Second, the consulting revenue continues during the platform build period, providing ongoing operating cushion. The honest gap: we do not have a confirmed monthly burn figure in the materials — this must be confirmed before any Earlybird meeting because they will ask. Frame the answer around burn multiple: revenue divided by cash consumed. At >€2M revenue with zero raised, the burn multiple on the consulting business is effectively 0.
slides.transition_to_next: Given this financial picture, here is exactly what we are asking for, how we will deploy it, and what milestones the €3M will unlock.

ZIM grant as non-dilutive capital is directly relevant to Earlybird's capital efficiency thesis
Series A trigger metrics (€1.5-2M ARR, 15+ platform customers) give Earlybird a clear underwriting framework for their follow-on decision

slides.title: €3M Seed — Build the Platform, Win the Category
slides.headline: The €3M Seed funds 18 months of platform engineering, first 10 platform customers, and EU expansion activation — with €237K of R&D already co-funded by the German government.
bullets: Raise: €3M Seed (pre-money valuation to be discussed). ZIM R&D grant of €237K (non-dilutive) already approved and reduces engineering capital requirement

Use of funds: ~60% Engineering (complete 7-layer platform build, 3 pilot customer deployments, ISO 27001/42001 readiness) | ~25% Sales & GTM (1 solution architect hire, direct sales to 10 platform customers, partner program activation) | ~15% Operations & Compliance (security audits, EU expansion groundwork, ISO certifications)

18-month milestones: MS1 — Full 7-layer platform deployed at 3 pilot customers (<6 weeks each, documented ROI) | MS2 — 10 paying platform customers, €600K platform ARR | MS3 — 5+ channel partners signed for EU expansion | MS4 — ISO 27001 + ISO 42001 certified (institutional procurement unlock)

Why Earlybird: European sovereignty thesis, enterprise AI infrastructure focus, portfolio synergies (remberg, HiveMQ, Aleph Alpha ecosystem). Seeking a lead investor who can open doors to German industrial and financial enterprise accounts in the DACH Mittelstand

That is non-trivial for Earlybird's due diligence. The use-of-funds breakdown should be stated confidently: 60% engineering, 25% GTM, 15% operations. If asked about runway, the consulting revenue continues as a secondary income stream during the platform build — the €3M is not the only cash input. ISO 27001 + 42001 milestones create institutional procurement unlock for German enterprise — directly relevant to Earlybird portfolio companies facing similar certification requirements
Explicit portfolio synergy mention (remberg, HiveMQ, Aleph Alpha) shows awareness of Earlybird's network value beyond capital

slides.title: Technical Moat: Integrated Security Architecture That Competitors Cannot Bolt On
slides.headline: The defensibility is not in any single layer — it is in the standardized integration of all seven, with agent-level security identity as the architectural primitive no incumbent has implemented.
bullets: 3D Security Policy Model (novel IP): Every AI agent ('Plox') is treated as a first-class security identity — not an extension of a human user account. Policy enforcement matrix: Dimension 1 (Who — agent identity, lifecycle status, certification tier) × Dimension 2 (What — read/write data, call LLM, invoke other agents) × Dimension 3 (Which Data — categories, granularity, PII classification). This goes beyond RBAC. No existing enterprise platform implements agent-level permission matrices with full audit trail — the architectural concept is patent-eligible and currently under DPMA trademark protection

Data moat — German-language PII detection: Proprietary fine-tuned NER model for German business documents (compounds, industry terminology, bilingual documents). Target: >95% precision/recall — outperforming English-optimized Presidio baseline on the specific document types Mittelstand enterprises generate. Trained on real anonymized client data from 25+ deployments

Hybrid RAG engine with Mittelstand-specific tuning: BM25 + Dense Retrieval + Cross-Encoder Reranking + semantic chunking, benchmarked against real heterogeneous document corpora (OCR-heavy PDFs, Excel exports, ERP data dumps, scanned contracts). Standard RAG benchmarks (BEIR, MTEB) do not test this document profile — NeuraPlox's benchmark corpus is itself a proprietary asset

Kubernetes-native multi-tenant isolation: Custom operator with CRD-defined agent lifecycle. Each agent has its own namespace, security context, resource quota, and network policy. Penetration-tested against container escape, network snooping, and side-channel extraction attacks. Open-source execution layer (L1-L3) builds community trust; proprietary control plane (L4-L7) retains competitive moat

AI commoditization defense: NeuraPlox is model-agnostic by design — LLM gateway supports OpenAI, Anthropic, Azure OpenAI, LLaMA, Mistral, and any future model. As foundation models commoditize, the value migrates up the stack to the security, governance, and orchestration layer — exactly where NeuraPlox's proprietary IP sits
metrics: >95% PII detection precision/recall target (German business documents)
15-30% better retrieval accuracy vs. pure vector search (Hybrid RAG, enterprise benchmarks)
7-layer architecture: TRL 4 components validated in live deployments → TRL 7 full platform (Seed target)
Patent pending: agent-centric governance architecture (DPMA trademark filed)
slides.speaker_notes: For Dr. Retterath specifically: the technical moat conversation should center on the 3D security policy model as the architectural primitive. Every enterprise will eventually need to control what their AI agents can do — but the infrastructure to enforce that at the agent identity level does not yet exist as a product. NeuraPlox is building the standard for that layer. The AI commoditization risk is proactively addressed: as GPT-5 and Claude 4 make foundation models cheap, the value moves to the orchestration, security, and governance layer — and that is precisely where NeuraPlox's proprietary IP is concentrated. The German-language PII model is a secondary moat: trained on real enterprise data that no US competitor has access to.
slides.transition_to_next: Thank you. We are building the infrastructure layer that European enterprises need to run AI agents safely in production. We welcome your questions.
vc_alignment_notes: Dr. Andre Retterath (Earlybird) specifically invests in AI infrastructure and developer tools — this slide is written for his technical evaluation framework
AI commoditization risk is proactively addressed as explicitly required by Earlybird's stated investment criteria
European data moat (German NER model trained on proprietary client data) is a sovereignty argument that maps to Earlybird's digital sovereignty thesis
Model-agnostic architecture means NeuraPlox benefits from foundation model commoditization rather than being threatened by it — this reframes a common investor objection

narrative_arc: Neurawork started not as a tech startup but as an AI deployment firm inside real Mittelstand enterprises. After 25+ live projects, one pattern repeated: ambition was never the problem — infrastructure was. NeuraPlox is the standardized AI operating platform built from that lived demand, not from a technology hypothesis. The deck moves from systemic market failure → timing urgency → the platform architecture that resolves it → proof from real deployments → a capital-efficient team with category-creation potential → a clear Seed ask with milestone-gated milestones for European expansion.
gaps_identified: No NPS or customer satisfaction data from existing consulting engagements
No exact burn rate figure — investor will push hard on this; needs a specific number or tight range
Co-founder's first name missing from all documents (listed as '[Vorname] Knoell') — must be confirmed before investor meetings
No named or anonymized customer logo evidence with specific before/after ROI metrics from a single project (aggregated 60% infrastructure reduction exists but single-case evidence needed)
Gross margin on consulting revenue stream not confirmed in documents — 30% cited as guidance but not validated
Net Dollar Retention (NDR) not available — consulting model makes this hard to calculate; needs framing
No specific sales cycle duration data from consulting-to-platform conversion attempts
No evidence of signed LOIs from the 3 ZIM pilot customers yet (planned milestone MS1)
Burn multiple cannot be precisely calculated without confirmed monthly burn figure
No advisory board or external validators listed — adds credibility for a lean team
Competitive win/loss rate data not available
Exact ACV distribution across consulting projects not disclosed
